## 

<span key="d722c3c8c9cf40b9a22b2236910ec4f0"><span offset-key="d722c3c8c9cf40b9a22b2236910ec4f0:0">Introduction to React for Complete Beginners</span></span>

<span key="e42f676334c94d849e3a56c40b44bcbf"><span offset-key="e42f676334c94d849e3a56c40b44bcbf:0">All of the code examples below will be included a second time at the bottom of this article as an embedded gist, so that it is properly syntax highlighted.</span></span>

<span key="a1fd60edf5bd4170b260181f0e5be016"><span offset-key="a1fd60edf5bd4170b260181f0e5be016:0">React uses a syntax extension of JavaScript called JSX that allows you to write HTML directly within JavaScript.</span></span>

<span key="ea750ba0d556479b835bcf604a8d7277"><span offset-key="ea750ba0d556479b835bcf604a8d7277:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span><span slate-void="true" key="1bd2823ea3d34ef39d87af7a9eee3a8b"></span>

<span key="7755b2ba0e2d4b69af185423a5a2d3a0"><span offset-key="7755b2ba0e2d4b69af185423a5a2d3a0:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span>

## 

<span key="602bcae55dec408eabb1832ba90dffb0"><span offset-key="602bcae55dec408eabb1832ba90dffb0:0">React</span></span>

> <span key="154596d7a194409f91fc11242b4ade06">*React uses a syntax extension of JavaScript called JSX that allows you to write HTML directly within JavaScript*</span>

> <span key="df5247493ab54bddba1a8730132f5b67">*because JSX is a syntactic extension of JavaScript, you can actually write JavaScript directly within JSX*</span>

> <span key="8e6e04cd5f0f44e1978ad9fc42b7a4f3">*include the code you want to be treated as JavaScript within curly braces: { ‘this is treated as JavaScript code’ }*</span>

> <span key="b38b57619f9643b4978cfb5b8824df36">*JSX code must be compiled into JavaScript*</span>

> <span key="8ae9e59954d04a7fb29d2bdedae09a96">*under the hood the challenges are calling ReactDOM.render (JSX, document.getElementById(‘root’))*</span>

> <span key="dcd6df12224947bea81d3429814c4c80">*One important thing to know about nested JSX is that it must return a single element.*</span>

> <span key="62047f0c930c4bda9f597c545a661267">*For instance, several JSX elements written as siblings with no parent wrapper element will not transpile.*</span>

<span key="18e3f1d16a104e239148c86995589625"><span offset-key="18e3f1d16a104e239148c86995589625:0"><span slate-zero-width="n">​</span></span></span>

## 

<span key="986f8fd76c2c4d319c29c622017af5c1"><span offset-key="986f8fd76c2c4d319c29c622017af5c1:0">What is React?</span></span>

<span key="2d8d1686a264450d8cc47bd7a4e68ce4"><span offset-key="2d8d1686a264450d8cc47bd7a4e68ce4:0">React is a declarative, efficient, and flexible JavaScript library for building user interfaces. It lets you compose complex UIs from small and isolated pieces of code called “components”.</span></span>

<span key="9a5670812275414f8c2e1ea4e06ee09c"><span offset-key="9a5670812275414f8c2e1ea4e06ee09c:0">React has a few different kinds of components, but we’ll start with </span>`React.Component`<span offset-key="9a5670812275414f8c2e1ea4e06ee09c:2"> subclasses:</span></span>

1

<span key="7441a3d36f14415eaf7113d42c4ff3ea"><span offset-key="7441a3d36f14415eaf7113d42c4ff3ea:0">class ShoppingList extends React.Component {</span></span>

<span key="81d57a6907b945d2a2eefba9e97b64f8"><span offset-key="81d57a6907b945d2a2eefba9e97b64f8:0"> render() {</span></span>

<span key="a2cd999cfbe74706a8eff1860a412e2d"><span offset-key="a2cd999cfbe74706a8eff1860a412e2d:0">We’ll get to the funny XML-like tags soon. We use components to tell React what we want to see on the screen. When our data changes, React will efficiently update and re-render our components.</span></span>

<span key="2ece6c6ec4b94641aa0f9ce968d55180"><span offset-key="2ece6c6ec4b94641aa0f9ce968d55180:0">Here, ShoppingList is a </span>**React component class**<span offset-key="2ece6c6ec4b94641aa0f9ce968d55180:2">, or </span>**React component type**<span offset-key="2ece6c6ec4b94641aa0f9ce968d55180:4">. A component takes in parameters, called </span>`props`<span offset-key="2ece6c6ec4b94641aa0f9ce968d55180:6"> (short for “properties”), and returns a hierarchy of views to display via the </span>`render`<span offset-key="2ece6c6ec4b94641aa0f9ce968d55180:8"> method.</span></span>

<span key="19d66195d7854695b32a2fda122818f3"><span offset-key="19d66195d7854695b32a2fda122818f3:0">The </span>`render`<span offset-key="19d66195d7854695b32a2fda122818f3:2"> method returns a </span>*description*<span offset-key="19d66195d7854695b32a2fda122818f3:4"> of what you want to see on the screen. React takes the description and displays the result. In particular, </span>`render`<span offset-key="19d66195d7854695b32a2fda122818f3:6"> returns a </span>**React element**<span offset-key="19d66195d7854695b32a2fda122818f3:8">, which is a lightweight description of what to render. Most React developers use a special syntax called “JSX” which makes these structures easier to write. The </span>`<div />`<span offset-key="19d66195d7854695b32a2fda122818f3:10"> syntax is transformed at build time to </span>`React.createElement('div')`<span offset-key="19d66195d7854695b32a2fda122818f3:12">. The example above is equivalent to:</span></span>

1

<span key="d8e0e0c925d041eeb182148ead81035e"><span offset-key="d8e0e0c925d041eeb182148ead81035e:0">return React.createElement('div', {className: 'shopping-list'},</span></span>

2

<span key="adda9f47768742ba9e73945ce95b6c3e"><span offset-key="adda9f47768742ba9e73945ce95b6c3e:0"> React.createElement('h1', /\* ... h1 children ... \*/),</span></span>

3

<span key="8b1e0846b4d0472d89cadc76cb7f7987"><span offset-key="8b1e0846b4d0472d89cadc76cb7f7987:0"> React.createElement('ul', /\* ... ul children ... \*/)</span></span>

4

<span key="91ccbe8fc12e414ca89ee9f150667a32"><span offset-key="91ccbe8fc12e414ca89ee9f150667a32:0">);</span></span>

### 

<span key="5cb4552404664d8e8961719d6bf343bb"><span offset-key="5cb4552404664d8e8961719d6bf343bb:0">To put comments inside JSX, you use the syntax {/\* \*/} to wrap around the comment text.</span></span>

<span key="b5f258fd6bc54c61bfcb2f408868dc9e"><span offset-key="b5f258fd6bc54c61bfcb2f408868dc9e:0">To put comments inside JSX, you use the syntax {/\* \*/} to wrap around the comment text.</span></span>

<span key="0e862f7ce2bf4ecabc74cb279431d065"><span offset-key="0e862f7ce2bf4ecabc74cb279431d065:0">The code editor has a JSX element similar to what you created in the last challenge. Add a comment somewhere within the provided div element, without modifying the existing h1 or p elements.</span></span>

1

<span key="49caadeb25a34fa096adf896b9f5946a"><span offset-key="49caadeb25a34fa096adf896b9f5946a:0">const JSX = (</span></span>

> <span key="5a957a5574e84b5b924e2c9f4963657a">*With React, we can render this JSX directly to the HTML DOM using React’s rendering API known as ReactDOM.*</span>

> <span key="f9ab8179822c4266b1e4f8de7015ad8f">*ReactDOM offers a simple method to render React elements to the DOM which looks like this:*</span>

<span key="3b26fa947d774179a1ef0c933b550e4b">`ReactDOM.render(componentToRender, targetNode)`</span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="958abad8f91d4ae78d04200cad9855b4"><span offset-key="958abad8f91d4ae78d04200cad9855b4:0">the first argument is the React element or component that you want to render,</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="cefcd193172b4dc2ab2079c74812a102"><span offset-key="cefcd193172b4dc2ab2079c74812a102:0">and the second argument is the DOM node that you want to render the component to.</span></span>

> <span key="0faaf56797d44c17957405a7033700fd">*ReactDOM.render() must be called after the JSX element declarations, just like how you must declare variables before using them.*</span>

> <span key="ceed30fd3efb4e1d8cfb1f3c5adc84c1">*key difference in JSX is that you can no longer use the word class to define HTML classes.*</span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="267ac8a3c03f48e990767ed6da10f070"><span offset-key="267ac8a3c03f48e990767ed6da10f070:0">— -> This is because class is a reserved word in JavaScript. Instead, JSX uses className</span></span>

> <span key="aff2f83589274891b6f5415f623a1498">*the naming convention for all HTML attributes and event references in JSX become camelCase*</span>

> <span key="60a3c1b097074982b25eac1f10cf3909">*a click event in JSX is onClick, instead of onclick. Likewise, onchange becomes onChange. While this is a subtle difference, it is an important one to keep in mind moving forward.*</span>

## 

<span key="7898d8731c7143d7b5a1a00c7ac2d255"><span offset-key="7898d8731c7143d7b5a1a00c7ac2d255:0">React: Learn About Self-Closing JSX Tags</span></span>

<span key="3fcd9679afa1450ea37ea8d155d94680"><span offset-key="3fcd9679afa1450ea37ea8d155d94680:0">-Another important way in which JSX differs from HTML is in the idea of the self-closing tag.</span></span>

> <span key="80d2715574e144f2870ddb0dca6664c6">*In HTML, almost all tags have both an opening and closing tag:*<span offset-key="80d2715574e144f2870ddb0dca6664c6:1"> </span>`<div></div>;`<span offset-key="80d2715574e144f2870ddb0dca6664c6:3"> </span>*the closing tag always has a forward slash before the tag name that you are closing.*</span>

> <span key="b8b33108f7b2415888bf2dc22d35f5b7">*there are special instances in HTML called “self-closing tags”, or tags that don’t require both an opening and closing tag before another tag can start.*</span>

> <span key="9a45ce37a7914b698f40fd0b35e82fb8">*For example the line-break tag can be written as*<span offset-key="9a45ce37a7914b698f40fd0b35e82fb8:1"> </span>`<br>`<span offset-key="9a45ce37a7914b698f40fd0b35e82fb8:3"> </span>*or as*<span offset-key="9a45ce37a7914b698f40fd0b35e82fb8:5"> </span>`<br />,`<span offset-key="9a45ce37a7914b698f40fd0b35e82fb8:7"> </span>*but should never be written as*<span offset-key="9a45ce37a7914b698f40fd0b35e82fb8:9"> </span>`<br></br>`*, since it doesn't contain any content.*</span>

> <span key="2bef3dd03eef47ddacd6a5b63302a0b6">*In JSX, the rules are a little different. Any JSX element can be written with a self-closing tag, and every element must be closed.*<span offset-key="2bef3dd03eef47ddacd6a5b63302a0b6:1"> </span>*The line-break tag, for example, must always be written as*<span offset-key="2bef3dd03eef47ddacd6a5b63302a0b6:3"> </span>`<br />`<span offset-key="2bef3dd03eef47ddacd6a5b63302a0b6:5"> </span>*in order to be valid JSX that can be transpiled.*<span offset-key="2bef3dd03eef47ddacd6a5b63302a0b6:7"> </span>*A*<span offset-key="2bef3dd03eef47ddacd6a5b63302a0b6:9"> </span>`<div>`*, on the other hand, can be written as*<span offset-key="2bef3dd03eef47ddacd6a5b63302a0b6:12"> </span>`<div />`*or*`<div></div>`*.*<span offset-key="2bef3dd03eef47ddacd6a5b63302a0b6:17"> </span>*The difference is that in the first syntax version there is no way to include anything in the*<span offset-key="2bef3dd03eef47ddacd6a5b63302a0b6:19"> </span>`<div />`*.*</span>

<span key="6dc8c61e401347bd8726ed5f4d3baa7c"><span offset-key="6dc8c61e401347bd8726ed5f4d3baa7c:0">React: Create a Stateless Functional Component</span></span>

> <span key="5832d52a97e9490fbd6312e57925f6a0">*There are two ways to create a React component. The first way is to use a JavaScript function.*</span>

> <span key="a3cbc3412a1a4a07ba69153bb30c5c59">*Defining a component in this way creates a stateless functional component.*</span>

> <span key="3e31d0a5a0dc44fea9ca06e57249eb04">*think of a stateless component as one that can receive data and render it, but does not manage or track changes to that data.*</span>

### 

<span key="7350b628201740c6bab60628164e7fcc"><span offset-key="7350b628201740c6bab60628164e7fcc:0">To create a component with a function, you simply write a JavaScript function that returns either JSX or null</span></span>

<span key="44618d6fb47b4068bf532904249eb509"><span offset-key="44618d6fb47b4068bf532904249eb509:0">React: Create a React Component</span></span>

> <span key="aad0ba379f8445168b1c9cc57363f047">*The other way to define a React component is with the ES6 class syntax. In the following example, Kitten extends React.Component:*</span>

> <span key="08e70d96958e4afbbd58dc0bfa9f1e38">*This creates an ES6 class Kitten which extends the React.Component class.*</span>

> <span key="06c349c610d448afb0ba491af9a24eba">*So the Kitten class now has access to many useful React features, such as local state and lifecycle hooks.*</span>

> <span key="4b9eb37f39414988b774ec5a8a41ce54">*Also notice the Kitten class has a constructor defined within it that calls super()*</span>

> <span key="7d859d14d81647998011849db250fe33">*It uses super() to call the constructor of the parent class, in this case React.Component*</span>

> <span key="ad91a446c7ac47ddb5eb88ddae959799">*The constructor is a special method used during the initialization of objects that are created with the class keyword. It is best practice to call a component’s constructor with super, and pass props to both.*</span>

> <span key="4a3720b81c5e434899636d354622f748">*This makes sure the component is initialized properly. For now, know that it is standard for this code to be included.*</span>

## 

<span key="01ac3d2c0c9f4d1f8b3890150c85693f"><span offset-key="01ac3d2c0c9f4d1f8b3890150c85693f:0">React: Create a Component with Composition</span></span>

> <span key="9f7e0c8c587b438a854006cae8b640d3">*Imagine you are building an App and have created three components, a Navbar, Dashboard, and Footer.*</span>

> <span key="5b5e11aa23e249a79c6b32ddde152006">*To compose these components together, you could create an App parent component which renders each of these three components as children. To render a component as a child in a React component, you include the component name written as a custom HTML tag in the JSX.*</span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="e5b4c1b98a1743c8b1a66157eb26bed6"><span offset-key="e5b4c1b98a1743c8b1a66157eb26bed6:0">For example, in the render method you could write:</span></span>

1

<span key="3e8671ac881e45408d1f333b72164639"><span offset-key="3e8671ac881e45408d1f333b72164639:0">return (</span></span>

2

<span key="4c1bf02a658c42fea261f41b8d575e6d"><span offset-key="4c1bf02a658c42fea261f41b8d575e6d:0"> &lt;App></span></span>

3

<span key="1f6e888f98c5434e94b36c76bf68651a"><span offset-key="1f6e888f98c5434e94b36c76bf68651a:0"> &lt;Navbar /></span></span>

4

<span key="a956e433b81648199cbc22a6119b383d"><span offset-key="a956e433b81648199cbc22a6119b383d:0"> &lt;Dashboard /></span></span>

5

<span key="2fb1662a76b94d7b974418ec9eb7a03e"><span offset-key="2fb1662a76b94d7b974418ec9eb7a03e:0"> &lt;Footer /></span></span>

<span key="401a2d0c541148389d66a9d40ba8060b"><span offset-key="401a2d0c541148389d66a9d40ba8060b:0"> &lt;/App></span></span>

Copied!

> <span key="1dc7fd68306947368c181823eee60740">*When React encounters a custom HTML tag that references another component (a component name wrapped in &lt; /> like in this example), it renders the markup for that component in the location of the tag. This should illustrate the parent/child relationship between the App component and the Navbar, Dashboard, and Footer.*</span>

React: Learn About Self-Closing JSX Tags

<a href="/my-docs/medium-articles/my-articles/introduction-to-react-for-complete-beginners#fix-the-errors-in-the-code-editor-so-that-it-is-valid-jsx-and-successfully-transpiles.-make-sure-you" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-855088 r-dwliz8 r-1loqt21 r-18u37iz r-lqms97 r-dnmrzs r-iphfwy r-1guathk r-1h8ys4a r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr r-7xmw5f"></a>

Fix the errors in the code editor so that it is valid JSX and successfully transpiles. Make sure you don’t change any of the content — you only need to close tags where they are needed.

<a href="/my-docs/medium-articles/my-articles/introduction-to-react-for-complete-beginners#ans-1" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-855088 r-dwliz8 r-1loqt21 r-18u37iz r-lqms97 r-dnmrzs r-iphfwy r-1guathk r-1h8ys4a r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr r-7xmw5f"></a>

React: Create a Stateless Functional Component

<a href="/my-docs/medium-articles/my-articles/introduction-to-react-for-complete-beginners#the-code-editor-has-a-function-called-mycomponent.-complete-this-function-so-it-returns-a-single-div" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-855088 r-dwliz8 r-1loqt21 r-18u37iz r-lqms97 r-dnmrzs r-iphfwy r-1guathk r-1h8ys4a r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr r-7xmw5f"></a>

The code editor has a function called MyComponent. Complete this function so it returns a single div element which contains some string of text.

<a href="/my-docs/medium-articles/my-articles/introduction-to-react-for-complete-beginners#ans-2" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-855088 r-dwliz8 r-1loqt21 r-18u37iz r-lqms97 r-dnmrzs r-iphfwy r-1guathk r-1h8ys4a r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr r-7xmw5f"></a>

React: Create a React Component

<a href="/my-docs/medium-articles/my-articles/introduction-to-react-for-complete-beginners#mycomponent-is-defined-in-the-code-editor-using-class-syntax.-finish-writing-the-render-method-so-it" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-855088 r-dwliz8 r-1loqt21 r-18u37iz r-lqms97 r-dnmrzs r-iphfwy r-1guathk r-1h8ys4a r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr r-7xmw5f"></a>

MyComponent is defined in the code editor using class syntax. Finish writing the render method so it returns a div element that contains an h1 with the text Hello React!.

<a href="/my-docs/medium-articles/my-articles/introduction-to-react-for-complete-beginners#ans-3" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-855088 r-dwliz8 r-1loqt21 r-18u37iz r-lqms97 r-dnmrzs r-iphfwy r-1guathk r-1h8ys4a r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr r-7xmw5f"></a>
